questions.text: Which one of the following is the major regulator of carnitine acyltransferase I (CAT-I) activity?
questions.solution:
Malonyl CoA is the major regulator of CAT-I activity. Malonyl CoA inhibits CAT-I, thus preventing the entry of long-chain acyl groups into the mitochondrial matrix

¬†

The fate of fatty acid in the cell:

¬†

  • Fatty acids (FAs) bind to membrane receptors and enter the cytoplasm via transporters.
  • Fatty acyl CoA synthetase adds CoA to the fatty acids.
  • Carnitine Palmitoyl Transferase 1A (CPT1A) converts fatty acyl CoA to acylcarnitine, which crosses the mitochondrial outer membrane.
  • Inside the matrix, acylcarnitine exchanges with free carnitine through Carnitine Acyl Carnitine Transferase (CACT).
  • Carnitine Palmitoyl Transferase 2 (CPT2) then converts acylcarnitine back to acyl-CoA esters.

Regulation By CAT-I:

  • Mobilized fatty acids enter mitochondria for beta-oxidation.
  • Carnitine acyl transferase I (CAT-I) regulates this entry.
  • In Low energy states:
    • Conditions like diabetes and starvation,
    • Glucagon levels increase.
    • Increased glucagon decreases malonyl CoA levels.
    • Reduced malonyl CoA levels lead to increased beta-oxidation in the mitochondria.
  • In High energy states:
    • Insulin levels are high.
    • Increased insulin increases malonyl CoA levels.
    • Increased malonyl CoA leads to decreased fatty acid oxidation
    • Hence, Acyl CoA gets stored in the form of TAG in the cells

Insulin and glucagon (Option A and B) do not directly influence CAT-1 but their levels indirectly influence it, by increasing or decreasing malonyl COA levels.
¬†

ATP (Option D) does not directly regulate CAT-I activity.

¬†

¬†

questions.text: What is the Total and Net ATP used in the complete oxidation of Arachidonic acid?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A)¬†136, 134

Explanation:

The oxidation of arachidonic acid occurs in the mitochondria via thiolysis when C2 units of it degrade once at a time to generate FADH2, NADH, and Acetyl-CoA.

N = number of carbons in the fatty acid, here, N= 20 (Arachidonic acid is a 20C chain fatty acid)

N/2 = of acetyl CoA produced

N/2 ‚Äì 1 = rounds need to fully metabolize the fatty acid, FADH2, NADH produced.

  • Number of Acetyl-CoA produced = 20/2 = 10
  • Number of NADH and FADH2 produced = 20/2 ‚Äî1 = 9 each.

The 10 Acetyl-CoA then moves in the citrate cycle to produce 3 NADH, 1 FADH2, and 1 GTP per Acetyl-CoA.

  • So, the number of NADH produced = 30,
  • The number of FADH2 produced = 10
  • The number of GTP = 10.

¬†

The ATP conversions:

  • 1 GTP= 1 ATP
  • 1 NADH = 2.5 ATP
  • 1 FADH2= 1.5 ATP.

¬†

The number of ATPs produced before the Acetyl-CoA moves in the citrate cycle= 9 FADH2 + 9 NADH = 9(1.5) + 9(2.5) = 36 ATPs

The number of ATPs produced when the Acetyl-CoA moves in the citrate cycle. 30 NADH + 10 FADH2 + 1 GTP = 30(2.5) + 10(1.5) + 10(1) = 100 ATPs

Total ATPs produced= 100 +36 = 136

2 equivalents of ATP (ATPü°™ AMP +PPi) are used to activate fatty acids to make acyl-CoA; therefore the net yield is 2 fewer ATP molecules.

The true yield is 134 ATP (136 ‚àí 2 ATP).

Net ATPs produced=134

¬†

questions.text: A 3-y/o child is brought to the emergency department with symptoms of severe fatigue, vomiting, and episodes of hypoglycemia. Blood tests reveal low glucose levels without elevated ketone bodies, as indicated by a negative Rothera and Benedict tests. Further examination indicates a fatty liver. The child's mother gives h/o acute fatty liver during her pregnancy with the child. Which of the following deficiencies is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct answer : Option B- Long-Chain 3-Hydroxyacyl-CoA Dehydrogenase Deficiency¬†

  • The scenario describes a child with severe fatigue, vomiting, nonketotic hypoglycemia, and fatty liver, alongside a maternal history of acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP).
  • These features are characteristic of Long-Chain 3-Hydroxyacyl-CoA Dehydrogenase Deficiency.
    • This condition affects fatty acid oxidation and can manifest in both the child and mother, particularly with AFLP during pregnancy.
  • Other deficiencies listed do not specifically present with this combination of symptoms and maternal history.

¬†

FATTY ACID OXIDATION DEFECTS

CONGENITAL DEFECTS

ACQUIRED DEFECTS

1. CPT-I Deficiency:

  • Site: Liver
  • Pathophysiology: Leading to decreased fatty acid oxidation and ketogenesis, which can result in hypoglycemia (Option A ruled out)
¬†

2. CPT-II Deficiency:

  • Site: Primarily affecting skeletal muscle and potentially the liver in severe cases
¬†

3. Defects in Œ≤-oxidation Enzymes: 2 types:

¬†
  • Long and Short-Chain 3-Hydroxyacyl-CoA Dehydrogenase Deficiency: Can cause nonketotic hypoglycemia, coma, and fatty liver. May also contribute to acute fatty liver during pregnancy
¬†
  • 3-Ketoacyl-CoA Thiolase and HMG-CoA Lyase Deficiency: These deficiencies not only disrupt fatty acid oxidation but also affect the breakdown of leucine, a ketogenic amino acid.

1. Carnitine Deficiency:

  • Common in preterm babies
  • Cause:
    • Inadequate biosynthesis or renal leakage.
    • Hemolysis
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Impaired fatty acid oxidation‚Üíhypoglycemia & Lipid accumulation‚Üímuscular weakness (Option D ruled out)
¬†

2. Jamaican Vomiting Sickness:

¬†
  • Cause: Consuming unripe ackee fruit containing the toxin hypoglycin,
  • Pathophysiology: This condition inhibits medium- and short-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase, leading to hypoglycemia (Option C ruled out)

CLINICAL FEATURES
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Nonketotic Hypoglycemia
  • Lipid Accumulation
  • Dicarboxylic Aciduria
    • Marked by the excretion of C6‚ÄîC10 œâ-dicarboxylic acids and non-ketotic hypoglycemia
    • It arises from a lack of mitochondrial medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase.
  • Muscular Weakness due to the buildup of lipids in muscles
  • Coma
  • Fatty Liver
  • Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy: Due to Long-chain 3-hydroxyacyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency indicating a potential role of hormonal changes influencing enzyme activity.
  • Neurological Symptoms: Defects impacting fatty acid oxidation, especially those also affecting the breakdown of leucine.

¬†

Differential Diagnosis:

  1. DKA (Benedict+, Rothera+): This would present with high blood glucose and elevated ketone bodies, which is not the case here.
  2. Starvation ketosis (Benedict-, Rothera+): This can also cause non-ketotic hypoglycemia, but without the fatty liver findings.
  3. Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD): This amino acid disorder can impact fatty acid oxidation and cause hypoglycemia, but would likely present with a different pattern of symptoms.
  4. Type 1 Glycogen Storage Disease: This can also lead to fasting hypoglycemia, but would not typically involve fatty liver changes

questions.text: Which enzyme requires vitamin B12 for the isomerization of L-methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA during odd-chain fatty acid oxidation?
questions.solution:
Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase is the enzyme responsible for converting L-methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA, a crucial step in the oxidation of odd-chain fatty acids. This reaction requires vitamin B12 as a cofactor.

In vitamin B12 deficiency, the activity of methyl malonyl-CoA mutase is greatly reduced, leading to the accumulation of methyl malonyl-CoA and the subsequent excretion of methylmalonic acid in the urine (methylmalonic aciduria) and neurological side effects leading to mental retardation.

¬†

¬†

Propionyl-CoA carboxylase (Option A) is another enzyme in the pathway that carboxylates propionyl-CoA to D-methylmalonyl-CoA and requires biotin, not vitamin B12.

¬†

Methylmalonyl-CoA racemase (Option C) converts D-methylmalonyl-CoA to L-methylmalonyl-CoA, but this reaction also does not require vitamin B12.

¬†

Biotin (Option D) is a cofactor for other carboxylation reactions but is not directly involved in the isomerization of succinyl-CoA.

¬†

¬†

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the role of glucagon in ketogenesis during starvation?

choices.text: Glucagon decreases lipolysis and reduces ketogenesis.
Glucagon inhibits gluconeogenesis and promotes ketogenesis.
Glucagon increases lipolysis and stimulates ketogenesis.
Glucagon decreases fatty acid entry into mitochondria and inhibits ketogenesis.

questions.solution:
Glucagon increases lipolysis, releasing more fatty acids that the liver converts into ketone bodies, thereby stimulating ketogenesis.

Causes of Ketosis:

  1. Diabetes Mellitus:
    • Untreated diabetes mellitus causes ketosis due to insulin deficiency, which increases lipolysis and fatty acid oxidation.
    • This raises acetyl CoA levels, while reduced oxaloacetate limits TCA cycle activity.
    • The body then overproduces ketone bodies as it relies on fat metabolism for energy.
  2. Starvation:
    • During starvation, reduced dietary glucose shifts oxaloacetate to gluconeogenesis.
    • Increased lipolysis converts excess acetyl CoA to ketone bodies.
    • High glucagon levels promote ketogenesis, providing the brain with 75% of its energy from ketones.
    • Conditions like hyperemesis in early pregnancy can also cause ketosis.
    • Limited glucose boosts free fatty acid mobilization, with the liver converting them to ketones, regulated by carnitine palmitoyltransferase-I (CPT-I).

Explanation for Ketogenesis:

  1. Hormonal Regulation:
    • Glucagon: Increases in glucagon during starvation and diabetes mellitus inhibit glycolysis, activate gluconeogenesis and lipolysis, decrease malonyl CoA, and stimulate ketogenesis. A high glucagon-insulin ratio promotes ketosis.
    • Insulin: Opposes glucagon by favoring glycolysis, inhibiting gluconeogenesis, suppressing lipolysis, increasing malonyl CoA, and reducing ketogenesis.
  2. Regulation Levels of Ketone Body Formation:
    • Lipolysis: Mobilizes fatty acids.
    • Fatty Acid Entry to Mitochondria: Regulated by carnitine acyl transferase I (CAT-I) for beta-oxidation.
    • Oxidation of Acetyl CoA: Converts acetyl CoA to ketone bodies.

Glucagon decreases lipolysis and reduces ketogenesis. (Option A): Glucagon, in fact, increases lipolysis, which provides more fatty acids for ketogenesis.

¬†

Glucagon inhibits gluconeogenesis and promotes ketogenesis. (Option B): Glucagon activates gluconeogenesis and also promotes ketogenesis, but it does not inhibit gluconeogenesis.

¬†

Glucagon decreases fatty acid entry into mitochondria and inhibits ketogenesis. (Option D): Glucagon does not decrease fatty acid entry into mitochondria; rather, it promotes ketogenesis by increasing lipolysis and the availability of fatty acids.

questions.text: Which of the following organs can utilize ketone bodies for energy, and which enzyme is involved in their metabolism?
questions.solution:
The brain can use ketone bodies as an energy source, and Thiophorase is the enzyme that converts acetoacetate to acetoacetyl CoA, which is utilized by the brain.

¬†

KETOSIS

Ketone Bodies
  • Produced in the liver
  • Utilized by extrahepatic tissues due to the absence of Thiophorase enzyme in the liver

Tissues that use Ketone Bodies
  • Almost all tissues except:
    • Liver
    • Red blood cells (RBCs)
  • Tissues that prefer ketone bodies:
    • Heart muscle
    • Renal cortex
    • Placenta
¬†
  • Tissues that use ketone bodies only in the absence of glucose:
    • Skeletal muscle
    • Brain
¬†
  • Additional Tissues Using Ketone Bodies
    • Intestinal mucosal cells
    • Adipocytes

Enzyme Involved
  • Thiophorase: Converts acetoacetate to acetoacetyl CoA

Fatty Acids as Primary Energy Source During Starvation
  • Skeletal muscles
  • Heart
  • Liver

Energy Production Pathway
  • Acetoacetyl CoA enters the beta-oxidation pathway to produce energy

¬†

Liver- Thiophorase (Option A): The liver produces ketone bodies but does not utilize them due to the absence of the enzyme Thiophorase. Thiophorase is involved in ketone body metabolism but is not present in the liver.

¬†

Heart muscle- Acetyl-CoA carboxylase (Option B): While the heart muscle can utilize ketone bodies, the enzyme mentioned, acetyl-CoA carboxylase, is not involved in their metabolism. Instead, the correct enzyme is Thiophorase.


Liver- Carboxylase (Option D): The liver does not utilize ketone bodies due to the lack of Thiophorase, and Carboxylase is not involved in ketone body metabolism.

questions.text: Which of the following is an end product of beta-oxidation of odd-chain fatty acids?
questions.solution:
Propionyl-CoA is the actual end product of beta-oxidation of odd-chain fatty acids. The last cycle of beta-oxidation of odd-chain fatty acids produces propionyl-CoA, which is then converted to succinyl-CoA.

¬†

Beta Oxidation of Odd-Chain Fatty Acids

Odd-chain fatty acids undergo beta-oxidation in the same manner as even-chain fatty acids, with successive removal of 2-carbon units (acetyl-CoA). The process continues until the final three-carbon unit, propionyl-CoA, remains.

Fate of Propionyl-CoA

  • Carboxylation: Propionyl-CoA is carboxylated to D-methylmalonyl-CoA by a biotin-dependent carboxylase enzyme, using ATP for energy.
  • Racemization: D-methylmalonyl-CoA is then converted to L-methylmalonyl-CoA by a racemase enzyme.
  • Rearrangement: L-methylmalonyl-CoA is rearranged to succinyl-CoA by L-methylmalonyl-CoA mutase, which requires vitamin B12.
  • Entry into the TCA Cycle: Succinyl-CoA enters the TCA cycle and is converted to oxaloacetate.
  • Gluconeogenesis: Oxaloacetate from the TCA cycle can be used for gluconeogenesis to synthesize glucose.

Malonyl-CoA (Option B): This molecule is involved in the synthesis of fatty acids, not in their beta-oxidation. Therefore, it is not an end product of beta-oxidation of odd-chain fatty acids.

Succinyl-CoA (Option C): This molecule is produced from propionyl-CoA through a series of reactions, but it is not a direct end product of beta-oxidation. It is an intermediate in the citric acid cycle.

Pyruvate (Option D): This molecule is a key intermediate in glycolysis and gluconeogenesis, but it is not involved in the beta-oxidation of fatty acids.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Acetyl CoA metabolism?

choices.text: It is produced in the cytoplasm from glucose via pyruvate oxidation.
It can be transported directly across the mitochondrial membrane to the cytoplasm.
It is converted to citrate in the mitochondria
It is involved in the production of NADPH in the cytoplasm.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C)¬†It is converted to citrate in the mitochondria

Explanation

Acetyl CoA combines with oxaloacetate to form citrate in the mitochondria. Citrate can then be transported to the cytoplasm via the tricarboxylate transporter.

Production of Acetyl CoA:

  • From Glucose: Acetyl CoA is produced in the mitochondria from glucose via pyruvate oxidation. (Option A ruled out)
  • From Fatty Acids: Acetyl CoA is also a product of fatty acid Œ≤-oxidation within the mitochondria.

Transport from Mitochondria to Cytoplasm:

  • Citrate Shuttle: Acetyl CoA cannot readily cross the mitochondrial membrane. Instead, it combines with oxaloacetate to form citrate, which is transported to the cytoplasm via the tricarboxylate transporter. (Option B ruled out)
  • Conversion in Cytoplasm: In the cytoplasm, citrate is converted back to acetyl CoA and oxaloacetate by ATP-citrate lyase in the presence of CoA and ATP.

Fates of Acetyl CoA:

  1. Fatty Acid Synthesis:
    • Location: Cytoplasm.
    • Process: Acetyl CoA is the primary building block for lipogenesis, regulated by nutritional status and more active in well-fed individuals consuming carbohydrate-rich diets.
  2. Cholesterol Synthesis:
    • Precursor: Acetyl CoA is a precursor in cholesterol synthesis.
    • Activity: This pathway is less active compared to fatty acid synthesis, especially in the liver.
  3. Energy Production:
    • Citric Acid Cycle: Acetyl CoA can re-enter the mitochondria as citrate and participate in the citric acid cycle for ATP production.
    • NADPH Production: Oxaloacetate in the cytoplasm can be converted to malate and then to pyruvate, generating NADPH in the process. Pyruvate returns to the mitochondria and is converted back into acetyl CoA. (Option D ruled out)
  4. Ketogenesis:
    • Location: Liver mitochondria.
    • A high rate of fatty acid oxidation is common during starvation or in individuals with untreated diabetes mellitus.

¬†

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Fatty acid synthase (FAS) complex is true?

choices.text: The FAS complex synthesizes fatty acids exclusively in the mitochondria.
The primary product of the FAS complex is palmitic acid, a 16-carbon saturated fatty acid.
The FAS complex utilizes the same enzymes and intermediates as those found in Œ≤-oxidation.
Each subunit of the FAS complex consists of a single enzyme responsible for fatty acid synthesis.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B)¬†The primary product of the FAS complex is palmitic acid, a 16-carbon saturated fatty acid.

Explanation:

The primary product of the FAS complex is palmitic acid, which is a 16-carbon saturated fatty acid synthesized during fatty acid synthesis.

Fatty Acid Synthase (FAS) Complex Overview:

  • Location:
    • Cytoplasm (Option A ruled out)
    • Active in liver, adipose tissue, lactating mammary gland, kidney, and brain.
  • Actions:
    • De novo synthesis of fatty acids, primarily palmitic acid (16-carbon saturated fatty acid).
    • Not the reverse of Œ≤-oxidation; it involves different intermediates, enzymes, coenzymes, and regulatory mechanisms. (Option C ruled out)
  • Structure:
    • Multi-enzyme complex organized as a homodimer (two identical subunits).
    • Each subunit contains three domains, six enzymes, and an acyl carrier protein. (Option D ruled out)
    • Enhances efficiency by facilitating interactions between intermediates and active sites.
  • Subunits:
    • Domain 1 (Condensing Unit):
      • Acetyl transacylase
      • Malonyl transacylase
      • Œ≤-keto acyl synthase (condensing enzyme)
    • Domain 2 (Reduction Unit):
      • Acyl carrier protein (ACP)
      • Œ≤-keto acyl reductase
      • Dehydratase
      • Enoyl reductase
    • Domain 3 (Releasing Unit):
      • Thioesterase (deacylase)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the fatty acid synthesis mechanism is NOT TRUE?

choices.text: Acetyl-CoA is converted to malonyl-CoA by acetyl-CoA carboxylase.
The FAS complex is a homodimer with two identical subunits and six enzymes.
NADPH is primarily generated by the citric acid cycle.
Palmitate is the main product, which can be converted into shorter fatty acids.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C)¬†NADPH is primarily generated by the citric acid cycle.

Explanation:

NADPH is primarily generated through the pentose phosphate pathway, not the citric acid cycle.

Fatty Acid Synthesis Mechanism:

  • Rate-Limiting Step: Formation of malonyl-CoA
    • Enzyme: Acetyl-CoA carboxylase (multienzyme protein) (Option A ruled out)
    • Reaction: Acetyl-CoA + bicarbonate (HCO‚ÇÉ‚Åª) + ATP ‚Üí malonyl-CoA
  • Fatty Acid Synthase (FAS) Complex:
    • Structure: Homodimer composed of two identical subunits, each containing six enzymes and an acyl carrier protein (ACP). (Option B ruled out)
  • Synthesis Process:
    • Elongation Cycles: Each cycle lengthens the fatty acid chain by two carbons.
      • Priming:
        • Attach acetyl-CoA to one ACP and malonyl-CoA to the other ACP of the dimer.
      • Condensation:
        • Acetyl group attacks the methylene group of malonyl residue, catalyzed by 3-ketoacyl synthase, releasing CO‚ÇÇ and forming a 4-carbon unit.
      • Reduction, Dehydration, Reduction:
        • The 4-carbon unit undergoes a series of reactions using NADPH.
      • Transfer and Binding:
        • The saturated acyl chain is transferred to the other subunit‚Äôs ACP, and a new malonyl-CoA binds to the free ACP.
  • Elongation Cycle: Repeats six times, producing a 16-carbon palmitate bound to ACP. (Option D ruled out)
  • Thioesterase Role: Releases free palmitate from the FAS complex.
  • Shorter Fatty Acid Production: Specific thioesterase in mammary glands can release 8, 10, or 12-carbon fatty acids for milk lipid incorporation.
  • NADPH's Role: Essential cofactor for reduction steps, mainly sourced from:
    • Pentose phosphate pathway
    • Conversion of malate to pyruvate (malic enzyme)
    • Conversion of isocitrate to alpha-ketoglutarate (extramitochondrial isocitrate dehydrogenase)

  • Very long-chain fatty acids (>22C)

¬†

Functions of peroxisomes

  • Breakdown of Very-Long-Chain Fatty Acids (VLCFAs)
  • Energy Production by reducing the length of fatty acid chains, making them suitable for further oxidation in mitochondria.
  • Cholesterol Metabolism: Contribute to the shortening of the side chain of cholesterol in bile acid formation.
  • Involved in the synthesis of ether glycerolipids, which are essential components of cellular membranes.
  • Participate in the synthesis of cholesterol and dolichol, which are important for various cellular functions.
